did.abstract: Republican mayor of Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1945-1957. The collection consists of topical files on Ann Arbor municipal issues, business records from his real estate and automobile sales ventures, scrapbooks, and photographs

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Mayor William E. Brown (donor no. 3946); additional business materials came from William E. Brown III.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are not expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, William E. Brown papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: William E. Brown, Jr. was a successful Ann Arbor Michigan businessman specializing in real estate and automobile sales. From 1945 to 1957, he also served as Republican mayor the city.

scopecontent.p: The Brown papers have been arranged into the following series: Topical files; Other mayoralty papers (relating primarily to off-street parking); Scrapbooks; Business records; and Photographs. The Topical files are the largest portion of the collection and include correspondence, reports, newspaper clippings, and miscellanea concerning such issues as housing, the new city charter, off-street parking, the new Veterans Administration Hospital, planning for a new city hall, Brown's election campaigns, and the support given by Brown to Albert E. Cobo in his campaign for governor of Michigan in 1956. The scrapbooks, 1945-1962, contain newspaper clippings and other materials relating to his mayoralty.

did.unittitle: Alger, Fred M (Michigan Secretary of State)
Business records (largely board of directors minutes)

scopecontent.p: Photographs illustrative of the city of Ann Arbor's building development during his mayoralty, including photos of a parking structure; also photos of plans for proposed Ann Arbor and Detroit, Michigan, civic complexes
